5.00.text: >>JG: who you may recognize from the Numberphile channel.

8.14.text: Some people may only know me through the Numberphile channel, but--

11.46.text: >>TW: And also the zombie video--don't forget that.

13.30.text:
>>JG: The zombie video! AARGH!
>>TW: The zombie video--I managed to survive. I managed to survive.

15.72.text:
>>JG: I didn't. That was a shame.
>>TW: Well, yeah. [laughing]

18.36.text: >>JG: We've been released from Brady's basement--

23.56.text: because he likes to keep his experts on a shelf.

25.84.text:
>>TW: Pull one down.
>>JG: Yeah, pull one down, and then put him back again.

28.68.text:
So we've escaped, and we're going to talk about 
Alan Turing.

32.16.text: >>TW: You see, I thought this was Brady's basement.

34.62.text:
>>JG: Well, he's got a massive house. 
>>TW: He does. He really does.

40.68.text: >>TW: He means so much to me and you,

44.82.text: what would they know about him?

46.78.text: At the very least, I suppose a few people would know about his code breaking.

51.78.text: >>TW: A few people then may know about his dealing with computing.

55.96.text: His next big thing--he laid down the logic

59.12.text: of computing, before there were even computers, really.

61.38.text: He was one of the pioneers of the computing age.

65.22.text: >>TW: Father of computer science. I mean,

66.64.text: he solved the Entscheidungsproblem, isn't it?

71.62.text: >>TW: Entscheidungsproblem, which is the stopping problem.

73.02.text: Go look it up on Wikipedia.

74.36.text: It's a very nice little problem.

75.70.text: And he also did--he also talked about AI.

78.36.text: He was thinking about thinking machines.

82.34.text: So he is amazing, and the more I learn about him,

85.10.text: the more I grow to respect him,

87.28.text: and the more impressed I am with him.

89.10.text: >>TW: That was always the thing--the same here.

91.10.text: Because if you had done any of those things,

92.50.text: you would be classed as a genius,

95.28.text: The fact that he did all of those things,

98.62.text: >>JG: But today, we're going to talk about something

100.72.text: that perhaps he is less well-known for, but--

103.04.text:
>>TW: Which is a shame.
>>JG: which is a shame, because it was so big,

106.12.text: and so important, what he did.

108.64.text: But at the time, it was overlooked.

109.86.text: >>JG: OK, so what are we talking about?

113.58.text: It means just the creation of something

116.94.text: As you look around you, you can see the background

118.74.text: you've got trees, you've got people, grass--you know--

122.24.text: >>TW: Guys playing frisbee. Why should any of this be here?

126.06.text: >>JG: They just probably wanted to play frisbee.

128.30.text: And the grass just wanted to be here.

129.72.text: But why shouldn't there just be an amorphous blob of stuff?

132.70.text: Why shouldn't it all just spread out?

135.22.text: Why should it all come together?

138.82.text: >>TW: Well, different things for different things.

141.44.text: But of course, one question is

143.42.text: one answer is what Turing gave.

145.46.text: And so what Turing did is that he had this stupid idea.

148.72.text: He said let's take some chemical reactions--

158.34.text: That means that once you get the reactions occuring,

160.38.text: it will stop reacting after a time.

162.48.text: It will go to a place where it's happy, and not do anything.

164.48.text: >>JG: OK, I think I understand that. OK.

166.00.text: >>TW: Right. And then on top of that--

167.60.text: so we've got a stable state of chemical reactions,

170.32.text: and on top of that, we add diffusion.

171.94.text: And diffusion, as hopefully you all know,

176.82.text: >>TW: Ink in water, aerosols in the air--

179.62.text: so if you put scent on,

181.34.text: >>JG: And it will spread out uniformly--is that right?

183.50.text: So ink in water--you know, when you put a tea bag

186.20.text: in a cup of tea, the tea will spread out

188.20.text:
to make the whole thing brown.
>>JG: Right.

189.62.text:
>>TW: You don't get patches of brown here and there.
>>JG: OK.

196.88.text: Stupid idea: What happens if I put them together?

198.82.text: Well, of course you're going to get stable things.

202.70.text: And this is where the genius of Turing came in.

204.86.text: He saw something that no one else would have checked.

207.78.text: He found that if have these two things,

209.86.text: you put diffusion with stable reactions,

214.76.text: Oh, and what's brilliant is animal patterns.

216.86.text: That's where it really comes into its own.

218.86.text: >>JG: So this is what I've heard of, right.

220.76.text: So I've heard of it described as 'waves on cows.'

224.76.text: One really good way is what some people do,

227.18.text: is that--if you have a cymbal--you know,

229.68.text: a drum kit cymbal--and you hit it,

233.38.text: you'll find that it oscillates in certain modes.

236.88.text: If you pluck a guitar string, you'll find

241.36.text: And that's all these Turing reactions are doing.

247.02.text: >>TW: And that's where this--what people have done is made cow-shaped metal discs,

253.56.text: >>TW: There was one joke about--I was giving this talk,

255.94.text: and a young boy came up to me and said

257.48.text: "So is that how cows get their pattern--you have to hit them?"

259.80.text: No. No, no, no, no--this was just a metaphor.

265.40.text: >>JG: That's fun for the students after a hard day's conference.

268.30.text: >>TW: Yeah, well--a few drinks later, and cows everywhere.

272.46.text: But yeah--so, you hit the cow-shaped cymbals,

276.80.text: and if you image where the oscillations occur,

280.54.text: and you see the blotches start happening.

282.66.text: And it's all very much related to how big you are.

288.88.text:
>>JG: OK.
>>TW: It's the same with a small piece of string.

291.08.text: You know, you pluck a small string, you'll get one mode.

293.08.text: Bigger string, you can get two modes.

294.72.text: Bigger animal, you can get two patterns,

296.96.text: and there are some cows, I believe,

299.08.text: which have one half black, one half white.

305.44.text: And then the bigger you are,

310.82.text: that if you have tapered domains,

312.92.text: then your pattern should get simpler, so, if you--

315.50.text: >>JG: Hang on--say that--so what's a tapered domain? What do you mean by that?

317.86.text: >>TW: So if you start with a wide end,

319.22.text: and you go to a very thin end, so--

320.30.text: >>JG: Is that the shape of the animal?

321.66.text: >>TW: Well, you've got--like you're going to a tail.

323.32.text:
>>JG: Yeah, yeah.
>>TW: You start from the torso, and you go to a tail,

325.32.text: or you start from an animal and you go to their arm.

329.60.text: And we do actually see this, on many monkeys,

333.34.text: you get this idea of going from one pattern to another.

336.56.text: On many cats--zebras, in fact--they do it.

339.60.text: So they go from striped to a very homogenous pattern.

341.94.text: But in biology what you find

346.36.text: And there is an animal called a tapir

349.32.text: who makes a mockery of Turing's theory.

352.40.text: It's a very--it's a wonderful animal.

354.04.text: It has a nose like that, and it snuffles around.

356.10.text: They're beautiful things, but I hate them because of this.

359.00.text: They start off, it's even worse--they start off

363.24.text: and then that changes as they go to--what it says is that,

366.74.text: you should start with spots on a large domain,

369.60.text: and go to stripes on thin domains.

371.76.text: So that's what you see on snakes.

373.54.text: But the tapir does it the other way around.

376.74.text: And what's even worse is that

378.44.text: it changes its pattern throughout its age.

381.04.text: So as it gets older, it just goes uniform, altogether.

385.18.text: >>JG: So how do you explain that?

390.00.text: >>TW: No, what we do is that we just say that that's out of our realm.

392.82.text: >>JG: Work left to do on that.

394.66.text: >>TW: Yeah, work left. There's always got to be something, you know.

396.96.text: >>JG: And maybe we'll finish--just one thing to finish    off,

399.86.text: because I know that Manchester University

406.34.text: in honor of Alan Turing. He wanted to

409.14.text: explain why there's a Fibonacci number of spirals.

416.90.text: We have a competition on who can grow the highest.

420.14.text: We've got a fiver on it. I'm losing badly.

427.04.text: >>TW: Oh! Oh! That's not in the rules is it? [laughing]

429.52.text: >>JG: I know. That's well out of order.

431.64.text: We're going to get onto this, I think, on Numberphile--

435.14.text: we're going to come back to that,

436.52.text: because we talked about it once.

438.62.text: But it's the same thing, isn't it?

443.84.text: So with that, it's more about how the packing works.

445.84.text: >>JG: But it was Turing again, right?

446.70.text: >>TW: It was Turing again--very much so.

448.32.text: I mean, this guy did so many things.

450.08.text: It makes you sick to think one man had all these ideas.

453.86.text: You know, I like to say about the Greeks, the Greeks weren't--

455.88.text: >>JG: I started off quite liking him,

457.96.text: but through the course of this video, I hate him.

462.70.text: Everyone says the Greeks were brilliant mathematicians.

464.26.text: No they weren't! They just had all the easy stuff to do!

470.96.text: Turing--not only did he do a lot,

475.24.text: I mean, the Greeks did brilliant things as well.

477.82.text: But, he just--as I say, a conference on just one idea for three days.

484.22.text: >>JG: OK, I think on that bombshell,

486.16.text: we've decided we hate Alan Turing.

490.80.text: >>JG: Yes, we'll leave it at that.
